Description: The molecular weight (molar mass) of the active pharmaceutical ingredient (API).
The predicted logarithm of the compound’s octanol–water partition coefficient (logP), indicating its lipophilicity.
The number of hydrogen atoms in the molecule that can form hydrogen bonds (donors).
The number of atoms in the molecule that can accept hydrogen bonds.
The number of rotatable bonds in the molecule, affecting molecular flexibility.
The total surface area of all polar atoms, primarily oxygen and nitrogen, including attached hydrogens; used to estimate drug absorption.
The total number of non-hydrogen atoms in the compound.
A quantitative measure of the molecular complexity, considering ring systems, stereochemistry, and branching.
Predicted aqueous solubility of the compound expressed as the logarithm of the solubility (mol/L). Lower values indicate lower solubility.
The amount of active pharmaceutical ingredient (API) present in a single tablet.
The total weight of tablet
The mass of powder (including air spaces) per unit volume before tapping.
The mass per unit volume of a powder after it has been tapped down to eliminate air gaps.
A measure of compressibility calculated as: (Tapped Density - Bulk Density) / Tapped Density × 100. Indicates flowability.
An index of powder flowability calculated as Tapped Density / Bulk Density.
The steepest angle at which a powder remains stable without sliding, indicating its flowability.
The thickness of the tablet measured with a caliper.
The time it takes for a tablet to become completely wet when placed in a fluid medium.
A common filler and binder used to provide structural integrity to tablets.
A sweet-tasting sugar alcohol used as a diluent and cooling agent in orodispersible tablets.
A lubricant used to prevent ingredients from sticking to manufacturing equipment.
A glidant that improves powder flow during tablet manufacturing.
A superdisintegrant that facilitates rapid breakup of tablets in the gastrointestinal tract.
A low-calorie artificial sweetener used to improve palatability.
A binder and film-forming agent that enhances tablet cohesion and release.
Natural binder or disintegrant (e.g., acacia, xanthan); improves tablet formation.
A biodegradable polymer used as a binder or bioadhesive.
An artificial sweetener used to mask the bitterness of active ingredients.
A surfactant used to enhance wetting and solubility of poorly soluble drugs.
A hydrophobic lubricant used in direct compression formulations.
A crosslinked polymer used as a superdisintegrant in fast-disintegrating tablets.
A starch-based superdisintegrant that swells upon hydration.
A film-forming polymer used for coating and controlled release.
A commonly used diluent that aids in tablet compressibility and palatability.
A glidant used to improve flow properties and prevent clumping.
Used to adjust pH or as a flavoring agent to mask bitterness.
A flavoring and cooling agent that improves mouthfeel.
A complexing agent that improves solubility and stability of APIs.
A natural sweetener derived from the Stevia plant.
A natural flavoring and antimicrobial agent.
A traditional disintegrant and binder in tablet formulations.
An effervescent agent used to facilitate disintegration through gas generation.
A natural fiber (psyllium) used as a swelling agent or disintegrant.
A commercially available co-processed excipient for fast-disintegrating tablets.
A brand of mannitol-based excipients designed for direct compression and disintegration.
A plasticizer or solubilizer used in formulations for improved drug release.
A pH-sensitive polymer used in taste-masking and modified-release coatings.
A lipid-based excipient used for sustained release formulations.
A calorie-free sweetener used to improve taste.
A strong ion-exchange resin used as a disintegrant.
A lubricant and glidant excipient used to improve flowability.
A series of ion-exchange resins (e.g., Indion 414) used as disintegrants or taste-masking agents.
A co-processed lactose-based excipient designed to improve compressibility.
An artificial sweetener used to mask unpleasant tastes.
A glidant used to enhance flow and reduce moisture sensitivity.
A potent artificial sweetener used in low concentrations for taste improvement.
A sugar-based diluent and sweetener often used in chewable and ODT formulations.
A herbal excipient potentially used for its bioactive or binding properties.
A natural gelling agent and disintegrant derived from seaweed.
Used as a filler, pH buffer, or source of calcium.
A co-processed excipient system designed specifically for orodispersible tablets.
A co-spray-dried lactose–cellulose blend used as a filler and binder.
A colorant used to improve tablet appearance.
Likely a duplicate/misspelling of Aerosil (colloidal silicon dioxide).
A lubricant and binder for direct compression formulations.
A diluent and binder commonly used in tablet formulations.
A natural binder or disintegrant derived from plant mucilage.
Ground Nut Shells
A co-processed excipient blend for direct compression with good flow properties.
A clay-based filler or absorbent used in tablet formulations.
A preservative used to prevent microbial growth in formulations.
A flavoring agent and mild analgesic, also used in effervescent ODTs.

co-processed super-disintegrating agent,A blend of crospovidone
and sodium starch glycolate and ethanol.
The force required to break a tablet by compression.
The tendency of a tablet to crumble, expressed as a percentage weight loss after tumbling.
The consistency of API content among tablets, usually expressed as a percentage of label claim.
The amount of water absorbed by the tablet, calculated by weight difference before and after wetting.
The time taken for a tablet to completely disintegrate in a liquid medium under specific conditions.
